persons.name: ChristopherGlaser
persons.description: a pharmaceutical chemist of the 17th century, the mineral glaserite is named after him.

persons.name: Johann RudolfGlauber
persons.description: German-Dutch alchemist and chemist. He discovered sodium sulphate in 1625 which was named 'Glauber's salt'.

persons.name: Roger JosephBoscovich
persons.description: Physicist, astronomer and mathematician born in Croatia but lived and worked mainly in Italy and France. Boscovich's work makes him one of the forerunners of atomic theory.

persons.name: Louis XIV
persons.description: King of France from 1643 until death - the 'Sun King'.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: FrancescoPetrarch
persons.description: An Italian poet and scholar, famous for his love sonnets. Davy wrote a poem called 'Vaucluse' inspired by Petrarch's poetry on the river Sorgue and Vaucluse valley in the Provence region of France and called him the 'bard of provence' in another poem, which John Davy published with the title 'Banks of the Rhone'.

persons.name: Cosimo IIIde' Medici
persons.description: Grand Duke of Tuscany (1670-1723).

persons.name: FrancescoPetrarch
persons.description: An Italian poet and scholar, famous for his love sonnets. Davy wrote a poem called 'Vaucluse' inspired by Petrarch's poetry on the river Sorgue and Vaucluse valley in the Provence region of France and called him the 'bard of provence' in another poem, which John Davy published with the title 'Banks of the Rhone'.

persons.name: JohnMayow
persons.description: Cornish physiologist and chemist, investigated respiration especially. FRSL.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: RobertHooke
persons.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

persons.name: Jean-BaptisteColbert
persons.description: a French statesman who served as First Minister of State from 1661 until his death in 1683 under the rule of King Louis XIV. He founded the Academy of Sciences in Paris.

persons.name: WilhelmHomberg
persons.description: German natural philosopher

places.name: Jakarta
places.description: formerly Batavia, the capital and largest metropolis of Indonesia.

persons.name: LouisLemery
persons.description: The son of scientist Nicolas Lemery, Louis was appointed physician at the Hôtel-Dieu de Paris in 1710, and became demonstrator of chemistry at the Jardin du Roi in 1731.

persons.name: NicolasLemery
persons.description: French chemist, born at Rouen. He was one of the first to develop theories on acid-base chemistry.

persons.name: WilhelmHomberg
persons.description: German natural philosopher

persons.name: WilhelmHomberg
persons.description: German natural philosopher

persons.name: Georg ErnstStahl
persons.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: Étienne FrançoisGeoffroy
persons.description: French physician and chemist, best known for his 1718 affinity tables. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: Jean-Baptiste deSénac
persons.description: French physician who made extensive studies of the heart.

persons.name: SlareFrederick
persons.description: Physician and chemist who worked for Robert Boyle. FRSL.

persons.name: JeanRey
persons.description: French physician and chemist.

persons.name: JohnMayow
persons.description: Cornish physiologist and chemist, investigated respiration especially. FRSL.

persons.name: RobertBoyle
persons.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

persons.name: RobertHooke
persons.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

persons.name: OleBorch
persons.description: Danish royal physician who taught Nicolas Steno.

persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: JosephPriestley
persons.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

persons.name: StephenHales
persons.description: English clergyman who made major contributions to a range of scientific fields including botany, pneumatic chemistry and physiology.  FRSL.

persons.name: JosephBlack
persons.description: From 1766, Professor of Medcine and Chemistry at the University of Edinburgh. Discovered latent heat and fixed air, later renamed carbon dioxide. A correspondent of James Watt and Thomas Beddoes (who studied under him).

persons.name: JosephBlack
persons.description: From 1766, Professor of Medcine and Chemistry at the University of Edinburgh. Discovered latent heat and fixed air, later renamed carbon dioxide. A correspondent of James Watt and Thomas Beddoes (who studied under him).

persons.name: WilliamBrownrigg
persons.description: Cumberland physician and chemist. FRSL.

persons.name: Johann FriedrichMayer
persons.description: German pastor and agriculturalist.

persons.name: DavidMacbride
persons.description: Irish physician, medical writer and lecturer who contributed to the understanding of scurvy. His Experimental Essays (1764) combined the gas theories of Joseph Black and Sir John Pringle.

persons.name: JosephBlack
persons.description: From 1766, Professor of Medcine and Chemistry at the University of Edinburgh. Discovered latent heat and fixed air, later renamed carbon dioxide. A correspondent of James Watt and Thomas Beddoes (who studied under him).

persons.name: Torbern OlafBergman
persons.description: Swedish chemist and mineralogist. At some point Davy acquired a set of letters from Bergman to Franz Schwediaur written in the 1780s which are retained in the Royal Institution (RI MS HD/27/A). ForMemRSL.

persons.name: HenryCavendish
persons.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

places.name: Grotto del Cane
places.description: A cave by the Lake of Agnano, in southern Italy, that has a high concentration of carbon dioxide. Dogs were used to demonstrate this as a kind of tourist attraction, which the Shelleys refused to allow when they visited.

places.name: England
places.description: England is a country that is part of the United Kingdom. It is located on the island of Great Britain, of which it covers approximately 62%, and over 100 smaller adjacent islands.

persons.name: JanIngenhousz
persons.description: Dutch-born British physiologist, biologist and chemist. He was one of the discoverers of the process of photosynthesis. FRSL.
